qas.question: What did critics believe about The Sun and Lord Kilbracken's ideas on AIDS?

answers.text: The Sun and Lord Kilbracken cherry-picked the results from one specific study while ignoring other data reports on HIV infection and not just AIDS infection

qas.question: What did Lord Kilbracken think of The Sun's editorial?

answers.text: Lord Kilbracken himself criticised The Sun's editorial and the headline of its news story

qas.question: Who criticized The Sun for its reporting on AIDS and HIV?
What did David Randall say about the Sun's AIDS story?

answers.text: The Sun's story was one of the worst cases of journalistic malpractice in recent history

qas.question: In what textbook did David Randall write his opinion?

context: Critics stated that both <a0_0>The Sun and Lord Kilbracken cherry-picked the results from one specific study while ignoring other data reports on HIV infection and not just AIDS infection<a0_0/>, which the critics viewed as unethical politicisation of a medical issue. <a1_0>Lord Kilbracken himself criticised The Sun's editorial and the headline of its news story<a1_0/>; he stated that while he thought that gay people were more at risk of developing AIDS it was still wrong to imply that no one else could catch the disease. <a2_0>The Press Council<a2_0/> condemned The Sun for committing what it called a "gross distortion". The Sun later ran an apology, which they ran on Page 28. Journalist David Randall argued in the textbook <a4_0>The Universal Journalist<a4_0/> that <a3_0>The Sun's story was one of the worst cases of journalistic malpractice in recent history<a3_0/>, putting its own readers in harm's way.
